The central idea was simple but risky. A robot that can change its body in real time. Not through software, but through physical reconfiguration. Shape-shifting robots sound impressive, but in practice, most robots are locked into one body, one role, and one set of limits. Once the hardware is built, flexibility usually ends. So when Limx Dynamics introduced TRON02 as a robot that can physically reconfigure itself, the real question wasn't how it looks. It was whether that flexibility survives real world stress. [music] Because changing form isn't just modular parts. Its balance, its control logic, its safety systems that don't fall apart the moment the robot moves differently than expected. That's exactly where most modular robots fail. Tron02 avoids that trap by being designed around a true triform architecture from the start. The same core system can operate as a dual arm manipulation platform, a wheeled leg mobile system, or a full bipedal walker. This isn't a cosmetic swap. Each form is meant to handle a different class of tasks from precise manipulation to terrain navigation without breaking the control stack underneath. But flexibility alone doesn't mean much if the robot can't handle real load. And this is where Limx Dynamics chose a very bold way to prove their point. In one demonstration, Tron02 appears without legs, suspended only by its arms. It grips a gymnastic ring, the kind used in strength training, and hangs freely in the air. At first, the test looks controlled and simple. Two water bottles are attached to the robot's body. Tron02 pulls up. Each lift looks deliberate, almost calm, like the robot is being warmed up rather than tested. Then, the moment changes. Japan also built a walking chair designed to help elderly people. And while many countries are using robots to replace workers, Japan has found a hidden method. Using robots to give jobs to people with severe physical disabilities. And it all starts with a robot making a basketball shot that looks ordinary until you realize what's really happening. Toyota developed CUE, an AI powered basketball robot created to study precision, repetition, and learning through motion. This is the same robot that set a Guinness World Record by making over 2,000 consecutive free throws, a level of consistency no human player could physically sustain. When CU steps up to the free throw line, the process begins instantly. Cameras and sensors track the hoop, measure distance, and determine the robot's exact position. Inside the system, software calculates force, [music] launch angle, and release timing to keep every shot controlled and repeatable. Once the ball is released, the analysis continues. If the shot goes in, CU records what worked. If the shot misses, the robot studies the error and adjusts the next attempt almost immediately. Every shot becomes data and every outcome improves accuracy. Sui does not experience fatigue or loss of focus. When conditions change, the robot recalculates calmly and continues. It also does not copy human shooting form, developing its own motion based purely on reliability. This is not about basketball skill. It is a demonstration of how robots learn space, timing, and precision at scale. Watching a robot hit thousands of [music] perfect shots feels unreal. It shows how far machines have come. Instead of focusing on appearance alone, Erica is designed around behavior. The robot maintains eye contact, listens without interrupting, nods during conversation, and times responses carefully. Japan is a country shaped by mountains, earthquakes, and narrow infrastructure. Not every environment is flat, stable, or designed for wheels. To move through those conditions, Kawasaki developed Cori, a four-legged robot built for balance rather than speed. Instead of forcing the ground to cooperate, Corio adapts itself to whatever terrain lies underneath. Each leg [music] operates independently. When the ground slopes, shifts, or sinks slightly, the robot redistributes its weight smoothly to remain stable. Movement stays controlled and deliberate even on loose soil, steps [music] or uneven surfaces. This makes Corio suitable for places where falling could be dangerous. In Japan, this matters for disaster response, infrastructure inspection, and work in remote or damaged areas where humans face higher risk. Earthquakes, landslides, and aging structures often create environments that are difficult to access safely. Kawasaki's long experience in heavy machinery is visible in the design. The focus is traction, balance, and reliability, not appearance. Corio does not try to look human or friendly. It is designed to move correctly under pressure. Like many Japanese robotics projects, Corio reflects a careful philosophy. Technology is not built to rush ahead of people, but to support them, especially where conditions are hardest and mistakes [music] are costly. The level Japan has reached is insane. These hotels are built for workers, travelers, and commuters who need proper rest without stepping away from their daily routines. Most capsule hotels are located near metro stations, major railway hubs, and bullet train terminals, making them easy to access late at night or early in the morning. Hotels like 9 hours focus entirely on sleep quality, removing distractions and unnecessary features. The concept is simple. Arrive, sleep properly, and leave refreshed. More modern capsule hotels such as the millennials quietly integrate sleep technology. Lighting fades gradually instead of switching off suddenly, allowing the body to slow down naturally.
